title: Priceline ends 'Name Your Own Price' deals for rental cars
text:
Priceline ends 'Name Your Own Price' deals for rental cars

CLOSE

Priceline.com customers will now see this when they try to book rental cars. They will no longer "Name Their Own Price." They will get "Express Deals." (Photo: Priceline)

Priceline will no longer offer “Name Your Own Price” rental car deals starting today.

The online travel agency (OTA)--which gained fame for the so-called NYOP model for airfares, rental cars and hotels--says it will now move to offering “Express Deals” for rental cars. Rather than bidding on rental cars and finding out later if they have a reservation, travelers will now know their price ahead of booking and will immediately get that booking confirmed.

Priceline already suspended NYOP option for airlines in 2016.

As of this morning, travelers will only be able to name their own price on hotel rooms.

Priceline’s Express Deals will offer the same deals for rental cars, including some that will provide up to 40% of savings, says Bill Jose, senior vice president of rental cars at Priceline.com.

The new process, he says, will be easier and faster.

“With rental cars, we have seen the consumers prefer Express Deals, and as a result we chose to make this switch,” he says. “The main benefit to consumers with this switch to Express Deals is with speed. Name Your Own Price for rental cars required consumers to bid and wait. With Express Deals, those steps are eliminated.”

Websites such as Priceline and Hotwire did well with the NYOP model for a while. But hotel companies have pushed back in recent years, offering incentives to travelers who book directly with their websites.

For instance, those who book with OTAs generally don’t get loyalty program points. And hotels argue that they can deal better with changes to reservations and problems on the ground when they have direct bookings.

That said, hotels also benefit from unloading unused inventory on sites such as Priceline and mobile apps such as Hotel Tonight.

The NYOP model won’t completely end for now.

Hotwire, one of Priceline’s biggest competitors, has “Hot Rate” opaque deals for hotels, rental cars and airfares. For hotels, travelers enter the date, location and star rating they would like. The hotel name is revealed only after they book, and all reservations are final.

It also has Hot Rate airfare deals. For instance, a search for a flight from JFK to LAX on May 11 produced a deal if the traveler is willing to depart sometime between 6 a.m. and 10 p.m. All the details, including the airline, are revealed after booking.

A similar process works for rental cars.

Priceline says it will continue to offer NYOP for hotel rooms.

“Priceline.com does not have plans to move away from Name Your Own Price for hotels,” Jose says. “Travelers see value in that offering and continue to book millions of deals at prices that are not available elsewhere.”
